awd_titl_txt: Theoretical Approaches to Multi-Scale Complex Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical and data-centric computational research and education with an aim to advance the understanding of complex materials. In a perfect crystal, periodically repeating a fundamental structural unit of atoms can generate the entire atomic structure of the material. The theoretical description of such a structure of atoms leads to the elegant explanation of many properties of crystalline or near crystalline materials. By contrast, in complex materials such as glasses, additional rich structures appear on length scales between the atomic and the macroscopic scales. These features make understanding a wide range of materials from ordinary window glass to high temperature superconductors which can conduct electricity without resistance challenging.

A goal of this project is to seek and quantify important structures in glassy materials - not by looking for particular known patterns- but rather by an unbiased analysis of structural data while invoking general physical principles. To address this challenge, the PI will broaden network analysis and computer vision methods to pinpoint and quantify the salient features of complex materials across different scales of length and time. This project will introduce new mathematical techniques for studying complex heterogeneous dynamics of both classical and quantum systems. The research will be done in close contact with experimental research groups around the world. The theoretical and data intensive computational study, in combination with experimental observations, is expected to lead to a deeper understanding of the structure of complex materials and systems including neural circuits, and enable progress in other disciplines. The techniques developed in this award will enhance cross-fertilization between condensed matter physics and other areas with multi-scale architectures such as medical imaging, bioinformatics, and communication networks. In collaboration with experimental neuroscientists, the PI aims to apply theoretical and data-centric computational tools developed in the course of research on materials to the visual neural circuits of the brain.  

This project supports training graduate students as well as further developing courses on advanced statistical mechanics and quantum information. The PI will also engage high school and undergraduate students to design software packages that illustrate the use of some of the methods developed during the course of the research.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical and data-centric computational research and education in theoretical condensed matter physics of materials with complex structure. The PI aims to develop and explore a new framework involving empirical data combined with ideas from data mining and network theory, Fokker-Planck, and other methods, to systematically uncover natural structures across a broad range of spatial and temporal scales. Analysis of experimental data of structural glasses and complex electronic materials will be performed with the aid of methods developed in the course of the project. Research will, specifically, be conducted along several directions: (1) The PI aims to employ ideas from statistical mechanics and network theory to unveil natural building blocks in disparate complex materials. The analysis will be performed on both experimental and simulation results in various materials systems including metallic glass alloys and electronic systems. As a byproduct, new concepts and tools will be developed and applied to optimization as well as imaging problems of wide interest. In collaboration with neuroscientists, the PI plans to apply developed tools to the study of the structure of the circuitry of the visual system of the brain. (2) The project will probe for low temperature quantum dynamical heterogeneities in cuprate superconductors and other electronic systems through a direct analysis of experimental data. Novel quantum effects at high temperatures will be further investigated.  (3) Fokker-Planck methods will be applied to the study of structure and evolution of viscous systems. (4) The PI will investigate the mechanical properties of complex systems, in particular how they may respond to external shear, and ascertain associated length scales.

This project provides a multidisciplinary research environment and an opportunity for students to learn a multitude of valuable techniques, including: molecular dynamics, image and network analysis, and data mining, in the context of close connection to experiments. The PI aims to review and communicate current ideas in network science, statistical mechanics, and condensed matter physics to graduate students through new courses. He also plans to engage high school and undergraduate students to design software packages that illustrate the use of some of the methods developed during the course of the research.

por.por_cntn:
The most notable outcome of this project is a new approach to understand glasses. Surprisingly, although "supercooled" liquids and the glassy structures that they "freeze" into are all around us (and have been known and used by humans for millennia), they are not at all understood. In 1995, Nobel Prize winner Philip Anderson stated that glasses are ``the deepest and most interesting unsolved problem in solid state theory''. More than two decades later, these systems remain no less enigmatic.  All theoretical approaches thus far called for new concepts and posit the existence of exotic temperature scales that are radically different from those in equilibrium solids and liquids. In this project, we studied these ubiquitous materials by employing a much more mundane approach. Specifically, we analyzed these systems by merely using the standard, well known, tools of quantum mechanics with no additional assumptions. To our surprise, the resulting theory led to predictions for the structure and dynamics that hold over a very large range of scales. In particular, the theory that we arrived at predicts a functional form for the viscosity that holds over sixteen decades of time scales (i.e., over times differing by a factor of ten million billion). Common lore asserts that quantum mechanics is typically important for understanding very small spatial scales (such as those of the atom). However, quantum mechanics is not limited to such problems alone. In this project, we analyzed the long time dynamics of supercooled liquids in the "eigenstate representation" of quantum mechanics. This turned out to be far simpler than the traditional classical formulation involving many equations of motion that need to be (and unfortunately cannot be exactly) solved. Our theory can still be recast classically via "microstates" (a classical ``phase space'' caricature of quantum mechanical eigenstates). However, the cleanest derivation is that in the quantum mechanical language. 

Although it has long been known that quantum mechanical effects appear on large spatial scales in solids (e.g., the replicated periodic ordering of atoms in a crystal gives rise to "electronic bands" that can be viewed as an extension of atomic levels over an entire solid), the traditional held belief has been that the understanding of glasses and liquids is a hard classical problems that requires new tools and ideas to approximate the equations of motion in order to tease out their salient features. The results of this project may trigger a reinvestigation of these beliefs. In particular, the prediction for the viscosity and structure of glassformers invokes only one well known important temperature scale- the conventional equilibrium melting temperature. The project does not assume the existence of an exotic unseen new transitions in order to rationalize the behaviors of glasses and supercooled liquids. Regardless of the specific theoretical approach of the PI, the fact that all liquids adhere to the newly found unique functional form for the viscosity in which there are no special temperature scales apart from those present in equilibrium suggests that indeed the "glass transition" and the conventional melting transitions may have much more in common than is currently realized.

Practically, since glasses are so commercially important, simple predictive functional forms  for their behaviors have long been desired. 

En route to investigating these systems, the PI derived various new relations that link dynamics with equilibrium thermodynamics and impose fundamental limits on the motions in thermal systems.

Another outcome concerns the continued development by the PI of machine learning tools and their applications to diverse complex physical systems. Nearly a decade ago, the PI introduced automated unsupervised machine learning techniques to the analysis of various complex systems. In the current project, these ideas have been further developed by the PI. The resulting algorithms are currently used by the PI in the analysis of medical images with the goal of applying these to real-time surgeries. 

Other results concern

(i) The analysis of quantum entanglement in many body systems via effective temperatures.


(ii) The demonstration that popular  "fracton" models that have been recently advocated for storing quantum information are, in fact, mathematically exactly solvable. The exact solutions suggest that some of these systems may, unfortunately, be susceptible to thermal noise.


(iii) The introduction of the notion of "partially flat bands" and demonstrating how these may give to enhanced superconductivity and correlations,


(iv) Demonstrating, theoretically, that a hybrid of materials known as "topological insulators" and superconductors may yield excitations with an effective fractional charge and angular momentum.


(v) Introducing a new class of spin glass systems and showing that the age old problem concerning the number of ground states in spin glasses with continuous couplings is ill-defined and that earlier seemingly conflicting predictions by different groups are in fact both correct. (Depending on an intricate order of limits, different results can be found.)

The PI and his collaborators also found a host of other findings.
